Segmental Analysis

By Production Technology, Which Segment Accounts for the Dominant Market Share?

Electric arc furnace production represents the dominant force in the green steel market, capturing 54.0% of total market share in 2026. This technology encompasses solutions featuring electricity-powered steelmaking from scrap metal feedstock, including advanced ultra-high-power furnace designs and renewable energy integration capabilities that enable low-carbon steel production through recycling-based circular economy approaches worldwide.

By End-Use, Which Segment Accounts for the Largest Market Share?

Automotive & transportation dominates the green steel end-use landscape with a 38.0% market share in 2026, reflecting the critical role of low-carbon materials in supporting automotive industry decarbonization strategies and electric vehicle manufacturing sustainability objectives worldwide.

The automotive & transportation segment's market leadership is reinforced by automaker sustainability commitments, supply chain emission reduction mandates, and consumer demand for environmentally responsible vehicle production driving green steel specifications.

What are the Drivers, Restraints, and Key Trends of the Green Steel Market?

The green steel market is driven by rising corporate net-zero commitments and scope 3 emission reduction targets, increasing demand for low-carbon steel across automotive and construction value chains. Strengthening carbon pricing mechanisms and emissions trading systems are further improving the economic case for green steel under carbon-constrained regulatory environments. Growing investor scrutiny and sustainable finance requirements are also encouraging steel producers to integrate environmental performance into capital access and competitive positioning.

Market restraints include high capital investment requirements for green steel facilities, particularly hydrogen-based direct reduction plants with significant infrastructure and renewable power costs. Limited availability of green hydrogen and supporting infrastructure constrains production scalability and operational reliability. Variations in technology maturity and limited operational experience further slow adoption, requiring extended commissioning and validation periods.

Key trends include accelerating hydrogen-based steelmaking projects in Europe and North America, supported by government funding and policy incentives. Expansion of high-capacity electric arc furnace infrastructure is also improving efficiency and lowering production costs, although alternative decarbonization pathways could influence long-term adoption dynamics.

Analysis of the Green Steel Market by Key Countries

Country CAGR (2026-2036) Canada 8.1% Sweden 7.8% USA 7.4% China 6.9% Germany 6.5% India 5.9% Japan 5.3%

How is Canada Leading Global Market Expansion in Green Steel?

Canada demonstrates the strongest growth potential in the green steel market, recording a CAGR of 8.1% through 2036. Leadership is driven by large-scale hydrogen direct reduction investments, abundant hydroelectric power enabling cost-effective green hydrogen production, and strategic positioning as a clean steel supplier to North America. Growth is concentrated in Quebec, Ontario, and Alberta, where renewable energy availability aligns with existing steel infrastructure.

Steel producers are advancing hydrogen-based steelmaking and electric arc furnace modernization, while automotive and construction supply chains support downstream demand. Government-backed clean technology funding, carbon pricing mechanisms, and critical mineral development continue to reinforce Canada’s green steel expansion.

Why is Sweden Emerging as a Technology Leadership Market in Green Steel?

Sweden grows at a 7.8% CAGR, driven by early commercialization of hydrogen-based steelmaking through initiatives such as HYBRIT. Industrial centers and northern mining regions are advancing fossil-free steel production supported by renewable electricity and integrated collaboration between steelmakers, miners, and energy providers.

Successful pilot operations and initial deliveries to automotive customers have validated technology readiness. Strong policy alignment and international demand for certified fossil-free steel continue to position Sweden as a global technology leader.

What is Driving Green Steel Market Growth in the USA?

The USA records a 7.4% CAGR, supported by electric vehicle manufacturing growth, sustainable infrastructure development, and federal incentives under clean manufacturing programs. Automotive decarbonization commitments and Buy Clean initiatives are encouraging adoption of low-carbon steel.

Established electric arc furnace infrastructure and growing scrap availability provide favorable conditions for green steel production. Regional variation reflects both EAF-led expansion and emerging hydrogen-based projects in renewable energy zones.

How does China Demonstrate Production Scale Leadership in Green Steel?

China grows at a 6.9% CAGR, driven by electric arc furnace expansion, scrap recycling integration, and industrial emission reduction mandates. Steel production hubs in Hebei, Jiangsu, Shandong, and Liaoning are transitioning capacity through EAF adoption and consolidation programs.

Renewable grid integration and environmental compliance requirements support reduced carbon intensity. Demand remains strong across construction, automotive, and infrastructure projects aligned with national carbon neutrality goals.

What positions Germany for Automotive Integration Leadership in Green Steel?

Germany expands at a 6.5% CAGR, driven by EU Green Deal requirements and automotive supply chain decarbonization. Steel producers in North Rhine-Westphalia, Bavaria, and Lower Saxony are investing in hydrogen direct reduction and facility conversion programs.

Close collaboration with automotive OEMs supports long-term supply agreements and carbon-certified steel adoption. Hydrogen infrastructure development and regulatory alignment continue to support Germany’s green steel positioning.

How is India Showing Infrastructure-Driven Growth in Green Steel Adoption?

India records a 5.9% CAGR, supported by infrastructure expansion, urban construction demand, and growing renewable energy capacity. Adoption is concentrated in industrial regions such as Maharashtra, Gujarat, Tamil Nadu, and Karnataka.

Steel producers are expanding electric arc furnace capacity and exploring cleaner production pathways to meet domestic demand. Renewable energy policies and tightening emission standards continue to encourage low-carbon steel adoption.

What Characterizes Japan’s Technology Collaboration Approach in Green Steel?

Japan grows at a 5.3% CAGR, driven by coordinated technology development with automotive manufacturers and a focus on incremental decarbonization. Steel producers collaborate with OEMs, trading houses, and technology partners to advance hydrogen steelmaking and carbon capture research. Emphasis remains on feasibility validation, application testing, and long-term transition planning aligned with Japanese industrial standards.

Competitive Landscape of the Green Steel Market

The green steel market is moderately concentrated, with around 10–15 meaningful participants competing across low-carbon steel production pathways. Competitive positioning is driven by decarbonization credibility, technology readiness, and long-term partnerships with automotive and construction customers rather than price-led dynamics.

ArcelorMittal, SSAB, and thyssenkrupp AG hold leading positions through large-scale production assets, advanced decarbonization programs, and active collaboration with automotive manufacturers seeking certified low-emission steel. These companies are investing heavily in hydrogen-based steelmaking, direct reduced iron technologies, and pilot projects to transition from conventional blast furnace operations.

Challengers such as Nucor Corporation, Tata Steel, and China BaoWu Steel Group compete through electric arc furnace expansion, scrap-based production, and renewable energy integration in key regional markets. Other producers including Emirates Steel Arkan, Outokumpu, and voestalpine AG focus on specific technologies or product segments, such as stainless and specialty steels.

Emerging entrants add competitive pressure through hydrogen-based facilities in regions with strong renewable energy access. Overall competitiveness favors producers combining scale, technology maturity, and end-user certification capabilities.

name: Clean Energy
title: State must be ready for energy challenges - Times Observer
description:
We at the Pennsylvania Environmental Council (PEC) supported Pennsylvania’s entry into the Regional Greenhouse Gas Initiative (RGGI) program because we believed that it would help to lessen some of the Commonwealth’s energy challenges.
RGGI could have been a powerful tool to provide the means to help meet these challenges, and others we’ve only barely begun to consider.
Failing to meet looming energy challenges puts Pennsylvania at risk of continually rising electricity costs and loss of jobs and economic opportunities to other states — particularly those tied to emerging technologies.
Other proposals hold promise for creating storage capacity, modernizing transmission systems, exploring new energy technologies like advanced geothermal, and building the state’s energy workforce.
But given rising demands, costs, and emissions inherent in how we currently operate, business as usual won’t meet Pennsylvania’s energy challenges and maintain our place as an innovative energy powerhouse.
text:
By Tom Gilbert

It took almost all year, but last month Gov. Josh Shapiro and the General Assembly finally agreed on a state budget. After 135 days of deadlock, it’s understandable that the predominant response to the deal and consequent resumption of funding critical government services has been one of relief. It’s to be expected that leaders are anxious to put the ordeal behind them. But as 2025 comes to a close, it is indisputable that Pennsylvania needs to both confront serious climate issues and reckon with the scale of the challenges we face with respect to energy affordability and reliability.

We at the Pennsylvania Environmental Council (PEC) supported Pennsylvania’s entry into the Regional Greenhouse Gas Initiative (RGGI) program because we believed that it would help to lessen some of the Commonwealth’s energy challenges. These challenges include new, power-hungry data centers and a backlog of new electric generating projects waiting to connect to the regional grid, which remain primary drivers of rising electric bills. We face long-term fuel and operational costs, and foreign markets holding our exports to increasingly higher standards of sustainability. RGGI could have been a powerful tool to provide the means to help meet these challenges, and others we’ve only barely begun to consider. It also could have helped with the worsening funding crisis for public transit systems statewide, another priority left unaddressed in budget negotiations.

Failing to meet looming energy challenges puts Pennsylvania at risk of continually rising electricity costs and loss of jobs and economic opportunities to other states — particularly those tied to emerging technologies. As only one example, PJM’s own market monitor has indicated that existing ratepayers have already paid $16.6 billion in increased electricity prices for the 2026-27 capacity auction due to existing and forecast data center demand alone.

So, what now?

Realistically, the benefits of RGGI’s cap-and-invest structure won’t be realized with any one policy. But multiple legislative and regulatory proposals are on the table in Harrisburg that can help move the needle on energy affordability, reliability, and availability. It’s more important than ever that these measures advance with due urgency.

At the top of the list is PRESS, a long-overdue expansion of Pennsylvania’s antiquated Alternative Energy Portfolio Standards, which PEC has advocated for nearly two decades. PRESS will further diversify the mix of energy sources our power generation system relies on while also reducing carbon pollution. Other elements of the Governor’s Lightning package, including updating our state’s energy efficiency program, securing community energy, and improving the siting process for new generation build, are also essential. Add to this two good ideas that passed key House committee votes last month: one helping clear a path for deployment of next-generation nuclear power, and another providing tax credits to help manufacturers save money and cut emissions through energy-efficiency upgrades. Other proposals hold promise for creating storage capacity, modernizing transmission systems, exploring new energy technologies like advanced geothermal, and building the state’s energy workforce.

All of these goals are within reach in 2026. But given rising demands, costs, and emissions inherent in how we currently operate, business as usual won’t meet Pennsylvania’s energy challenges and maintain our place as an innovative energy powerhouse. Government must lead by providing the right policies and incentives to ensure that Pennsylvania thrives. A sound energy policy can check all of the boxes. Let’s build the technologies of the future here, get more electrons on the grid, reduce emissions, grow our workforce, and put investment into making our systems and products better. 2026 must be the year we do what it takes to secure a prosperous clean energy future.

Tom Gilbert is President of the Pennsylvania Environmental Council (PEC).

text:
Tesla has just opened another very large DC fast-charging station: a new 60-stall Supercharging site is now available in Manning, South Carolina.

The location supports EV drivers traveling I-95, which, according to Max de Zegher, Tesla’s Director of Charging North America (@MdeZegher / X), is becoming as busy as I-5 on the West Coast and needs 100+ stalls along key exits.

The latest station is not only large, but it’s also equipped with a solar canopy. The peak power output is 325 kW, as Tesla installed V4 Supercharging dispensers combined with V3 power electronics cabinets. The base price is $0.34/kWh for Tesla EVs and $0.48/kWh for other EVs (since the station is available to Tesla’s NACS partners).

Mobile Superchargers for the Holiday Rush

Just like in previous years, Tesla is preparing for peak travel days by deploying Megapack Chargers and Mobile Supercharger Units.

The Megapack Chargers feature Megapack battery energy storage with Supercharging dispensers. The Mobile Supercharger Units are simply preassembled Superchargers that can be easily deployed wherever there is a power connection. Several such locations were installed in November.

Deployment of additional infrastructure builds on more conventional actions such as a site-opening push, proactive service visits, and attendants at some of our busiest sites, the company explains.

text:
By Lisa Sorg for Inside Climate News

Fewer inspections, weaker enforcement and less oversight: Deep cuts to state budgets and at the Environmental Protection Agency are preventing regulators from fully protecting the public from pollution, according to a report released today by the Environmental Integrity Project.

The financial crisis at these agencies is occurring amid the expansion of the fossil fuel, plastics and petrochemical industries, said EIP Executive Director Jen Duggan.

When states have fewer resources, Duggan said, “those protections, those rights that every American has under our environmental laws, are not being realized.”

President Trump’s budget proposal would decimate 2026 spending at the EPA by 55 percent, or $4.2 billion, according to the report. House Republicans are recommending cutting it by a quarter, while the Senate Appropriations Committee voted for a reduction of just 5 percent.

If enacted, these reductions would exacerbate the EPA’s financial plight. Over the last 15 years, the agency’s budget has been slashed by 40 percent, Duggan said, and its workforce by 18 percent. Since Trump began his second term, more than 3,000 EPA workers have retired or have been terminated as part of the administration’s gutting of the agency.

The upshot of these cuts is that states have to pick up the slack, which is central to EPA Administrator Lee Zeldin’s vision for the agency. In March, on the day he announced “the biggest deregulatory action in history,” Zeldin said he intended to “give power back to the states.”

However, the Trump administration has proposed eliminating most EPA grants to the states, undercutting their agencies’ ability to wield that power.

Texas lawmakers have cut by a third the budget for the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality over the last decade, accounting for inflation, the EIP report says. The agency has also struggled to retain employees; 30 percent of its workforce has less than two years of experience, and half have less than five years.

Kathryn Guerra worked for nearly four years at the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality, where she helped small businesses and local governments comply with regulations. Most recently, Guerra worked in the EPA Region 6 office overseeing environmental justice efforts, which the Trump administration eliminated this year.

She’s now the TCEQ campaign director for Public Citizen, a nonprofit advocacy group.

The funding cuts to TCEQ described in the report “render the agency largely ineffective,” Guerra said, “and cuts to the EPA will worsen that ineffectiveness.”

According to TCEQ’s biennial report to the Texas legislature, it takes an average of 351 days to process one enforcement case. The agency’s most recent enforcement report shows a backlog of 1,400 enforcement cases, Guerra said.

“Ultimately it means communities don’t get relief from the environmental harms those polluters are causing,” she said.

States with the deepest budget cuts to environmental agencies from 2010–2024, according to the report, are:

Mississippi—71 percent

South Dakota—61 percent

Alabama—49 percent

Texas—33 percent

Montana—32 percent

North Carolina is among the states whose budgets have contracted in the past 15 years. While the EIP report said the state Department of Environmental Quality’s budget had declined 32 percent from 2010-2014, an agency restructuring in 2015 makes quantifying the depth of the reductions difficult.

“These cuts have real impacts on the people of our state,” said Drew Ball, director of Southeast Campaigns for the Natural Resources Defense Council, on a press call about the report.

Ball also serves as a Buncombe County Commissioner in an area wrecked by Hurricane Helene in 2024.

“When a family in eastern North Carolina notices their tap water turning cloudy after a heavy rain, there are fewer staff who can investigate,” he went on. “There are fewer inspectors available to respond when hurricanes send flood waters through low lying areas, mixing industrial pollution, animal waste and storm water, the staff responsible for tracking and responding to those threats are being asked to do far more with far less.”

During the 2008 recession, North Carolina lawmakers cut DEQ’s budget, part of a statewide belt-tightening. However, the Republican-led legislature has not fully restored those reductions in more economically robust times and during an era of increased population growth.

From 2020 to 2024, census data show the state’s population has grown by more than 5 percent. But over the same period, when accounting for inflation, DEQ’s budget decreased.

In 2019, the DEQ budget was $97.4 million, according to state documents, equivalent to $123.7 million today.

The 2023 DEQ budget totalled $108.7 million, or $115.8 million in today’s money. That’s a 6 percent decrease compared with four years earlier.

Some of the agency’s functions rely on permitting fees. In at least one instance, a healthier environment has resulted in unexpected financial consequences. As state and federal regulations have made the air cleaner, Title V facilities, the largest air pollution sources, have decreased their emissions, according to a 2023 DEQ report to the legislature.

This has translated to a drop in “billable tons”—54 percent over a decade—that generate a portion of the agency’s revenue. Yet the state’s 300 Title V facilities still must be inspected and their permits renewed, even as the number of staff has decreased by 19 percent.

In 2024, the legislature increased the permit fee to help close the gap.

North Carolina had the largest staffing cuts at environmental agencies from 2010 to 2024, according to the report, though the same caveat related to the 2015 restructuring applies.

States with the next largest staffing cuts, 2010-2024, are:

Connecticut—26 percent

Arizona—25 percent

Louisiana—24 percent

Missouri and Kansas—20 percent

Adding to the budgetary crisis, it’s also been difficult for North Carolina DEQ to retain or hire employees. At its peak three years ago, the agency had vacancy rates that exceeded 20 percent. DEQ officials said at the time that agency wages, whose boundaries are set by the legislature, can’t compete with the private sector.

“Many families today live with waste in roadside ditches, wells that are too contaminated to drink from and constant fear about what the next storm will carry into their yards,” Ball said. “Yet the very agency responsible for protecting these families is facing a growing burden, with shrinking staff, shrinking budgets and shrinking political support, and now the federal government is proposing the deepest cuts to EPA in 40 years. That’s a recipe for disaster in states like ours.”

description:

text:
ATLANTA — State regulators granted Georgia Power the authority for an historic expansion of its capacity to generate electricity in a unanimous vote Friday.

The decision by the five elected members of the Public Service Commission, all Republicans, allows the privately-owned monopoly to build five gas-powered plants and supporting infrastructure while contracting for additional power from other suppliers.

Critics said the expansion, equivalent to five times the power output of the Hoover Dam, could cost up to $60 billion, saddling generations of Georgians with the bill.

The company asked for and got permission to add nearly 10 gigawatts of generating capacity, close to a 50% increase in its capacity. It said its forecasts showed voracious future demand from tech companies that will be building server warehouses to power the internet and artificial intelligence.

In a statement after the vote, Kim Greene, chairman, president, and CEO of Georgia Power, called the demand “projected unprecedented growth,” noting that the company had filed customer contracts with the commission this year for three gigawatts in new demand.

Critics contended that the forecast revenue, based on “trade secret” information that the public cannot see, was overly optimistic. If the demand does not materialize, they said, Georgia Power’s other customers would be left with the bill for the construction of that unneeded capacity.

To offset those concerns, the company pledged to shield existing customers from the cost of the expansion but only through 2031. Thereafter, the agreement allows for amendments to hit the brakes if demand does not materialize.

“Large load” customers, such as data centers, will pay for the expansion through the rates they are charged, the company said, but there remains a risk that the data centers do not come.

So Georgia Power addressed that by signing a “stipulated agreement” to allocate costs based on the current revenue forecasts that assume the demand will be there.

This “downward pressure” on rates will equal $8.50 a month for the typical residential customer, the company said.

Lawyers for opponents, including environmental organizations and renewable energy advocates, said there were undisclosed assumptions in Georgia Power’s calculations that they contended could create a countervailing “upward pressure” on residential bills.

They wanted the company to enter its calculations into the public record, so the commission could more easily hold it to account for its pledge in the future.

Lawyers for the Southern Environmental Law Center filed motions calling for the disclosure and for a 30-day delay on the vote.

“The point of this motion is not about whether it’s a good deal or a bad deal,” said Jennifer Whitfield, one of the lawyers. “It’s about … Georgia Power showing its work for the conclusions that are in the agreement so that we can enforce that agreement down the road.”

Her colleague, Bob Sherrier, added later: “We have a problem with the stipulation putting a number on the downward pressure but not a number on the upward pressure.”

Jason Shaw, chairman of the commission, denied the request, saying his agency already had all the necessary information from Georgia Power.

Then the commissioners voted for the expansion, with audience members shouting “shame,” “disgusting” and “sell out!”

Before the vote, members of the public got time to speak.

Some extolled the benefits of reliable power, saying big companies will not bring jobs to Georgia if the state cannot stay ahead of demand.

“It’s about being proactive rather than reacting too late,” said Susanne Reynolds, director of the Development Authority of Early County in southwest Georgia.

But most were furious about the expansion because of the potential cost for customers and the impact on the environment of burning more fossil fuel.

They also were unhappy with the timing of the vote, less than two weeks before January.

That is when two new commissioners, both Democrats, will take over the seats of the two Republicans they beat decisively in an election last month

Julie Jabaley said she would work hard to unseat the remaining three Republicans.

She was among the protesters escorted out of a similar hearing last week after they were told they had violated the commission’s rules on “decorum,” a word that Jabaley mocked.

“If you vote on this proposal today as is, you demonstrate an utter lack of respect for thousands of petitioners who have tried to decorously convince you that there’s a better way to fulfill your mission that consumers receive safe and reasonably priced services,” she said.

Jabaley said she wanted “clean, smart energy for the future” and was concerned about the cost of the expansion.

“If you proceed,” she said, “you will absolutely not be decent to the tens of thousands of Georgia Power customers on fixed or low incomes.”

text:
Everybody loves parks. While national parks are usually first on people’s mind when looking to enjoy nature, state parks are often more accessible and just as stunning. Unfortunately, many state parks are not adequately funded or maintained, but in a webinar hosted by advocate Calvin Floyd, and moderated by Len Montgomery, director of the Great Outdoors Campaign at Environment America, four state leaders shared how they’ve found success for their parks.

You can watch the webinar, sponsored by Environment America and the National Association of State Park Directors here:

Rodney Franklin became Division Director of Texas state parks in 2018 and has spent the entirety of his career dedicated to Texas state parks. He joined us to discuss the 90 sites and the state’s success establishing the Centennial Parks Conservation Fund. He also detailed the expansions and two new parks that resulted from the fund as well as a timeline for development.

Kristin Kosick, Chief of the Michigan state parks and recreation, outlined the funding breakdown of the state parks system. She also provided insight into the Recreation Passport, a state parks pass that Michigan residents can opt in for when they register their vehicles and out-of-state visitors can purchase as well.

Katie Lanter, the policy section manager who has been working for Colorado parks and wildlife since 2015, spoke about the Keep Colorado Wild Pass, another parks pass paired with vehicle registration. She described what the pass has funded and allowed them to accomplish.

Finally, Chris Padgett, the state parks administrator for Tennessee state parks, outlined the department’s growth and additions as well as the goal of adding 8 new parks by December 2026. He also discussed the Tennessee parks system’s goals of being the most accessible parks system by 2030 and the economic impact of having state parks.

Attendees asked panelists about funding breakdowns for each state, what criteria qualify new parks, clarifying questions about the vehicle registration passes, the role of donations, and more.

Learn more about Environment America’s conservation work here.

title: House Passes SPEED Act for Federal Energy Permitting Reform - Discovery Alert
description:
Understanding Federal Permitting Reform: Why the SPEED Act Matters What Is the SPEED Act and Its Core Objectives?
The Standardising Permitting and Expediting Economic Development (SPEED) Act, formally designated as H.R.
The renewable energy sector's support for permitting reform reflects practical recognition that environmental review streamlining benefits all energy infrastructure development, regardless of technology type.
Energy sector companies should begin preparing for potential SPEED Act implementation while maintaining flexibility regarding timeline and scope uncertainties.
The SPEED Act passage in the House represents just the beginning of what could be a transformative period for American energy infrastructure development.
text:
American energy infrastructure sits at a critical juncture where decades of regulatory complexity collide with unprecedented demand for domestic resource development. The intersection of environmental oversight, economic necessity, and national security considerations has created a permitting landscape that industry leaders characterise as fundamentally broken. Against this backdrop, federal lawmakers are attempting to recalibrate the balance between environmental protection and energy project development through comprehensive legislative reform targeting the foundational frameworks that govern major infrastructure decisions.

The current regulatory environment reflects layers of environmental review processes that evolved over more than five decades, creating what many stakeholders view as duplicative and time-intensive approval mechanisms. These systems, originally designed to ensure thorough environmental consideration, now face scrutiny for their role in delaying critical energy projects across multiple sectors. Furthermore, the growing consensus among diverse industry coalitions suggests that modernising these frameworks has become essential for maintaining America's competitive position in global energy markets while addressing domestic supply challenges.

Understanding Federal Permitting Reform: Why the SPEED Act Matters

What Is the SPEED Act and Its Core Objectives?

The Standardising Permitting and Expediting Economic Development (SPEED) Act, formally designated as H.R. 4776, represents a comprehensive legislative effort to restructure federal environmental review processes. According to Congress.gov's official bill summary, the legislation limits the scope of the National Environmental Policy Act of 1969 (NEPA) and modifies the environmental review of major federal actions under NEPA to generally limit the number of federal actions that trigger NEPA review and to expedite the review process.

The bill emerged through bipartisan collaboration between Representative Bruce Westerman (R-Arkansas), who serves as House Natural Resources Committee Chairman, and Representative Jared Golden (D-Maine). This cross-party sponsorship reflects the legislation's attempt to address concerns that transcend traditional political boundaries, particularly in regions where energy infrastructure development directly impacts local economies.

Core provisions of the SPEED Act focus on modernising NEPA review processes through several key mechanisms:

Reducing duplicative environmental assessments across federal agencies

Establishing more definitive timelines for project review completion

Limiting litigation opportunities that extend project approval cycles

Streamlining coordination between federal and state regulatory authorities

The American Petroleum Institute's President and CEO Mike Sommers characterised the legislation as a critical step toward modernising a federal permitting system, emphasising that by modernising NEPA and reducing duplicative reviews and litigation, this bill restores certainty and helps unlock the infrastructure needed to deliver affordable, reliable energy and meet growing demand.

How Does Current Federal Permitting Create Infrastructure Bottlenecks?

The existing federal permitting framework creates substantial operational challenges across multiple energy sectors through prolonged review cycles and regulatory uncertainty. For instance, industry representatives consistently identify these delays as primary obstacles to meeting domestic energy demand and maintaining competitive positioning in international markets, often requiring detailed mining permitting insights to navigate complex approval processes.

Current System Limitations:

Multi-agency coordination complexity requiring separate approvals from numerous federal departments

Overlapping review requirements between federal, state, and local jurisdictions

Extended litigation periods following initial approvals

Uncertain timeline expectations preventing effective project planning and capital allocation

Texas Independent Producers and Royalty Owners Association President Ed Longanecker emphasised that comprehensive permitting reform represents a strategic imperative for the country and industry. Without such reform, America's energy sector, particularly oil and natural gas, cannot operate at the pace or scale needed to meet domestic needs, support allies abroad, or ensure long-term affordability for consumers.

Independent Petroleum Association of America President and CEO Edith Naegele characterised the SPEED Act as a much-needed answer to years of independent oil and natural gas producers' concerns regarding energy infrastructure permitting. This perspective reflects widespread industry frustration with existing approval processes that many stakeholders view as outdated relative to current technological capabilities and economic realities.

National Ocean Industries Association President Erik Milito highlighted that permitting certainty remains essential to keeping investment, jobs, and energy production in the United States. He emphasised that a durable, effective permitting framework provides the foundation for the nation's economic strength, global competitiveness, and energy dominance.

The cumulative impact of these delays extends beyond individual project timelines to affect broader strategic planning across energy sectors. Companies must account for regulatory uncertainty in their capital deployment decisions, often leading to delayed investments or project relocations to jurisdictions with more predictable approval processes.

Legislative Journey and Political Dynamics

What Were the Voting Patterns in the House?

The SPEED Act passage in the House occurred on December 19, 2025, with a final vote tally of 221-196, demonstrating notable bipartisan support despite overall partisan divisions on environmental policy. The voting breakdown reveals interesting cross-party dynamics that suggest regional and economic factors influenced individual representatives' decisions beyond traditional party-line considerations.

Voting Breakdown Count Republicans in favour 210 Republicans against 1 Democrats in favour 11 Democrats against 195 Total Passage Margin 25 votes

The 11 Democratic supporters represent a significant bipartisan element in legislation that primarily aligns with Republican energy policy priorities. These crossover votes likely reflect constituents' economic interests in districts where energy infrastructure development provides substantial employment and tax revenue benefits.

The single Republican opposition vote suggests near-unanimous party support for permitting reform, indicating strong consensus within Republican caucus leadership regarding the legislation's strategic importance. This level of party unity often facilitates more effective advocacy during Senate consideration and potential conference committee negotiations.

Why Did This Bill Achieve Bipartisan Support Despite Political Divisions?

Several factors contributed to the SPEED Act's ability to attract Democratic support in a politically polarised environment. Regional economic considerations, national security implications, and practical infrastructure needs appear to have influenced representatives from districts with significant energy sector employment.

Key Factors Enabling Bipartisan Support:

Regional economic dependencies on energy infrastructure projects

National security framing emphasising domestic energy production capacity

Renewable energy sector benefits from streamlined permitting processes

Pragmatic recognition of infrastructure development necessities

American Exploration & Production Council CEO Anne Bradbury characterised the vote as a turning point to fix America's broken permitting system and lower energy costs for every American. She specifically credited Chairman Bruce Westerman and Representative Jared Golden's SPEED Act as a bipartisan breakthrough to responsibly streamline environmental reviews and end permitting lawfare that stifles all forms of energy development and drives up costs for American families.

Energy Workforce and Technology Council President Tim Tarpley reframed the discussion beyond economic considerations, stating that passing permitting reform represents not just an economic need, but a critical national security issue. This security-focused messaging likely resonated with representatives concerned about domestic energy independence and supply chain resilience, particularly given the strategic importance of critical minerals and energy security considerations.

The inclusion of renewable energy advocacy through organisations like Turn Forward, which focuses on American offshore wind power development, helped broaden the coalition supporting permitting reform. Hillary Bright, Turn Forward's Executive Director, emphasised that permitting delays remain one of the greatest obstacles to advancing U.S. energy projects essential to meeting unprecedented demand on the nation's electrical grid.

Representative Golden's participation as co-sponsor reflects Maine's interests in offshore wind development, where federal permitting delays significantly impact project timelines and economic benefits to coastal communities. This demonstrates how specific regional energy opportunities can create bipartisan incentives for regulatory reform.

Industry Impact Analysis Across Energy Sectors

How Will Oil and Gas Operations Benefit from NEPA Reforms?

Oil and gas sector stakeholders anticipate significant operational improvements from SPEED Act implementation, particularly regarding infrastructure development timelines and regulatory certainty. The current permitting environment creates substantial planning challenges for companies seeking to develop pipeline networks, processing facilities, and upstream production capacity.

Anticipated Oil and Gas Benefits:

Pipeline development acceleration through reduced inter-agency coordination delays

Drilling permit processing improvements enabling more responsive resource development

Infrastructure expansion opportunities in key production basins

Reduced regulatory compliance costs through streamlined approval processes

The American Petroleum Institute's support for the legislation reflects industry-wide recognition that current permitting processes significantly impact project economics and development timelines. By modernising NEPA and reducing duplicative reviews and litigation, the reforms could unlock infrastructure needed to deliver affordable, reliable energy and meet growing demand.

Texas Independent Producers and Royalty Owners Association's endorsement emphasises the strategic importance of permitting reform for maintaining America's energy sector competitiveness. The association represents nearly 3,000 members whose operations depend on efficient regulatory processes for project development and expansion activities.

Independent petroleum producers, represented by IPAA, face particular challenges from extended permitting processes due to their typically smaller operational scale and limited resources for navigating complex regulatory requirements. Streamlined approvals could enable these companies to respond more effectively to market opportunities and contribute to domestic production capacity.

What Does This Mean for Renewable Energy Development?

Renewable energy sectors stand to benefit substantially from SPEED Act provisions, despite some environmental groups' opposition to the legislation. The current federal permitting framework creates similar delays for renewable projects as for traditional energy infrastructure, often extending development timelines by multiple years.

Renewable Energy Sector Benefits:

Offshore wind project timeline acceleration through streamlined federal approvals

Solar and onshore wind permitting efficiency improvements

Grid interconnection approval acceleration enabling faster project completion

Transmission line development facilitation supporting renewable energy integration

Turn Forward's advocacy for the SPEED Act demonstrates renewable energy sector recognition that permitting delays represent fundamental obstacles to meeting America's growing electrical grid demands. Offshore wind projects, which require extensive federal coordination due to their location in federal waters, could experience particularly significant timeline improvements.

Hillary Bright emphasised that America faces skyrocketing energy demand and that offshore wind projects offer a proven way to provide utility-scale power to densely populated areas where resource diversity helps avoid grid disruptions and rising utility costs. The organisation advocates for bringing more viable, scalable American energy sources online through regulatory efficiency.

The renewable energy sector's support for permitting reform reflects practical recognition that environmental review streamlining benefits all energy infrastructure development, regardless of technology type. Solar, wind, and transmission projects currently face many of the same regulatory bottlenecks as traditional energy infrastructure.

How Could Mining and Critical Minerals Extraction Change?

Critical minerals extraction represents another sector where SPEED Act implementation could significantly impact domestic supply chain security and economic competitiveness. Current federal permitting processes for mining operations often extend development timelines well beyond those seen in other major mining jurisdictions globally.

Potential Mining Sector Impacts:

Domestic rare earth element project acceleration supporting technology supply chains

Lithium extraction permitting improvements enabling battery material production

Copper and base metals development streamlining supporting infrastructure construction

Strategic mineral security enhancement through domestic production capacity

The United States currently depends heavily on foreign sources for many critical minerals essential to renewable energy technologies, electric vehicles, and defence applications. Consequently, streamlined permitting processes could enable domestic projects to compete more effectively with international suppliers operating under different regulatory frameworks.

Mining projects typically require extensive environmental review due to their potential impacts on local ecosystems and water resources. However, SPEED Act provisions could reduce approval timelines while maintaining essential environmental safeguards through more efficient review processes, as demonstrated by evolving trends in the mining industry evolution.

Economic and Investment Implications

What Are the Projected Economic Benefits of Faster Permitting?

Economic analysis of permitting reform suggests substantial potential benefits across multiple sectors, though precise quantification depends on implementation details and industry response patterns. Accelerated project approval timelines could unlock significant capital investment that currently remains delayed due to regulatory uncertainty.

Projected Economic Impact Areas:

Job creation acceleration across energy infrastructure sectors

Infrastructure investment mobilisation through reduced regulatory risk

Regional economic development enhancement in energy-producing areas

Consumer energy cost reduction through increased domestic supply

The cumulative impact of faster permitting extends beyond individual projects to affect broader economic development patterns. Regions with significant energy resources could experience accelerated economic growth through more rapid project development and associated employment creation.

Investment capital currently held back due to permitting uncertainty represents a substantial potential economic catalyst. Private sector companies often delay major capital commitments until regulatory approval certainty increases, meaning permitting reform could trigger significant near-term investment deployment.

Regional Economic Multiplier Effects:

Direct employment in energy infrastructure construction and operation

Indirect economic benefits through local supplier networks and service providers

Induced economic activity from increased worker income and spending

Tax revenue enhancement for local and state governments

How Might This Affect Energy Infrastructure Investment Flows?

Investment patterns across energy infrastructure sectors could shift significantly following SPEED Act implementation, with potentially substantial implications for capital allocation and project development priorities. Reduced regulatory timelines and increased approval certainty typically encourage higher levels of private sector investment.

Investment Flow Considerations:

Private capital deployment acceleration in previously delayed projects

Public-private partnership opportunities expansion in transmission and renewable sectors

Foreign direct investment enhancement through improved regulatory predictability

Risk profile improvements attracting institutional investor participation

Energy infrastructure projects require substantial upfront capital investments with long-term payback periods, making regulatory uncertainty particularly challenging for project economics. In addition, streamlined permitting processes could improve project risk profiles sufficiently to attract additional institutional investment from pension funds, insurance companies, and other large-scale capital sources.

The transmission sector represents a particularly significant opportunity for investment acceleration, as grid modernisation and expansion require extensive federal coordination but offer substantial economic returns through improved system efficiency and renewable energy integration capabilities. Savvy investors recognise that comprehensive investment strategy insights are crucial when evaluating these emerging opportunities.

Senate Prospects and Implementation Challenges

What Are the Realistic Chances of Senate Passage?

The SPEED Act faces a more complex political environment in the Senate, where energy policy legislation typically requires broader bipartisan support for successful passage. Current Senate composition and historical voting patterns on energy infrastructure issues suggest the bill's prospects depend heavily on amendments and modifications during committee consideration.

Senate Consideration Factors:

Committee assignment and markup scheduling priorities

Key senator positioning on energy permitting reform

Amendment potential addressing environmental concerns

Timeline coordination with other legislative priorities

National Ocean Industries Association President Erik Milito emphasised that as the Senate takes up this legislation, Congress must work collaboratively to deliver the strongest possible permitting reform that provides real certainty, avoids unintended consequences, and supports investment across the full spectrum of America's energy economy.

The Senate's deliberative process typically involves more extensive stakeholder consultation and amendment consideration than House procedures. This could result in modifications addressing environmental groups' concerns while maintaining the legislation's core permitting reform objectives.

What Implementation Challenges Could Emerge?

Successful SPEED Act implementation would require substantial coordination across multiple federal agencies and adaptation of existing regulatory frameworks. The complexity of current environmental review processes suggests implementation challenges could emerge in several areas.

Potential Implementation Obstacles:

Federal agency resource allocation requirements for expedited reviews

State-federal coordination mechanisms development

Legal challenge management from opposition groups

Environmental compliance framework maintenance under accelerated timelines

Federal agencies currently managing NEPA reviews would need additional resources and modified procedures to implement accelerated approval processes while maintaining environmental protection standards. This could require significant training, system development, and organisational restructuring.

Interagency coordination represents another substantial implementation challenge, as many energy projects require approvals from multiple federal departments with different priorities and procedures. Streamlining these processes while maintaining appropriate oversight could prove technically and administratively complex.

Environmental and Community Considerations

How Do Environmental Groups View These Changes?

Environmental organisations have raised substantial concerns about SPEED Act provisions, arguing that accelerated permitting processes could compromise environmental protection and community consultation processes. Opposition groups worry that streamlined reviews might overlook important ecological and social impacts.

The Sierra Club, described as the most enduring and influential grassroots environmental organisation in the United States, has criticised the SPEED Act and coordinated opposition through a letter sent by more than 150 environmental and community groups to Congress opposing the legislation.

Environmental Group Concerns:

Environmental review thoroughness reduction under accelerated timelines

Community consultation process limitations

Cumulative impact assessment potential oversight

Long-term environmental monitoring framework adequacy

Opposition groups argue that current NEPA requirements serve essential functions in identifying and mitigating potential environmental impacts that might otherwise be overlooked in rapid development processes. They contend that thorough environmental review ultimately saves costs and prevents problems rather than creating unnecessary delays.

What Safeguards Remain Under the Reformed Framework?

Despite environmental groups' concerns, SPEED Act provisions maintain important environmental protection requirements while streamlining review processes. The legislation aims to improve efficiency rather than eliminate environmental consideration entirely.

Maintained Environmental Protections:

Environmental assessment requirements preservation with modified timelines

Scientific review standards continuation under expedited processes

Public participation opportunities maintenance in streamlined formats

Monitoring and compliance enforcement mechanisms retention

The challenge lies in balancing environmental protection thoroughness with development timeline efficiency. Successful implementation would require maintaining rigorous environmental standards while eliminating duplicative or unnecessarily prolonged review processes.

Strategic Scenarios for Energy Market Evolution

Scenario 1: Rapid Implementation and Industry Response

Under this scenario, SPEED Act implementation proceeds smoothly with minimal legal challenges, enabling rapid acceleration of energy infrastructure development across multiple sectors. Industry response could trigger significant near-term investment and project development activity.

Rapid Implementation Outcomes:

Project pipeline acceleration across oil, gas, and renewable sectors

Market competition intensification through increased development capacity

Regional energy hub emergence in areas with favourable resource and regulatory combinations

Supply chain localisation opportunities through domestic project expansion

This scenario could result in substantial economic benefits through job creation, increased energy production capacity, and enhanced supply chain resilience. However, it might also strain regulatory agency resources and create implementation challenges requiring careful management.

Scenario 2: Legal Challenges and Delayed Implementation

Alternative scenario development involves extensive legal challenges from environmental groups and other stakeholders, creating implementation delays and regulatory uncertainty that limit near-term benefits while prolonging current permitting challenges.

Delayed Implementation Impacts:

Court battle timeline extension affecting industry planning

Investment uncertainty continuation during legal proceedings

Alternative state-level approaches development by individual states

International competitiveness implications from continued delays

Extended legal challenges could undermine the legislation's intended benefits while creating additional uncertainty for industry planning and investment decisions. This scenario might prompt some companies to pursue alternative development strategies or consider international opportunities.

Scenario 3: Modified Senate Version and Compromise Framework

A middle-ground scenario involves Senate modifications addressing environmental concerns while maintaining core permitting reform objectives. This compromise approach might achieve broader bipartisan support while balancing development and environmental priorities.

Compromise Framework Elements:

Environmental safeguard enhancements addressing opposition concerns

Implementation timeline adjustments allowing gradual system adaptation

Stakeholder consultation expansion improving community engagement

Monitoring requirement strengthening ensuring environmental compliance

This scenario could provide the most durable long-term solution by building broader stakeholder consensus while achieving meaningful permitting improvements. However, compromise provisions might reduce some of the legislation's intended efficiency benefits.

Long-term Strategic Implications

How Could This Reshape America's Energy Landscape by 2030?

SPEED Act implementation could fundamentally alter America's energy development trajectory over the next decade, potentially accelerating domestic production capacity across multiple sectors while enhancing supply chain resilience and international competitiveness.

2030 Energy Landscape Projections:

Domestic energy production capacity substantial expansion across sectors

Energy independence enhancement through reduced import dependencies

Global energy market positioning strengthening through competitive advantages

Technology deployment acceleration enabling innovation and efficiency improvements

The cumulative impact of accelerated permitting could position the United States as a more dominant global energy supplier while reducing consumer costs through increased domestic production capacity. This transformation could affect international trade balances and geopolitical relationships significantly.

What Are the Broader Economic Competitiveness Considerations?

Beyond immediate energy sector impacts, SPEED Act implementation could enhance broader American economic competitiveness through reduced energy costs, improved supply chain reliability, and strengthened manufacturing capacity dependent on affordable energy inputs.

Competitiveness Enhancement Areas:

Manufacturing sector revival through competitive energy costs

Critical supply chain reshoring enabling domestic production capacity

Innovation ecosystem development supporting advanced energy technologies

International trade balance improvements through energy exports

Manufacturing industries that depend heavily on energy inputs could benefit substantially from increased domestic energy production and associated cost reductions. This could encourage reshoring of manufacturing operations previously relocated to countries with lower energy costs.

Key Takeaways and Next Steps

What Should Stakeholders Monitor in 2025?

The SPEED Act's journey through the Senate represents a critical phase requiring stakeholder attention to committee assignments, amendment proposals, and broader legislative scheduling priorities. Multiple factors will influence the bill's ultimate prospects and final form, particularly in light of potential developments from an executive order on mining permits that could complement these legislative efforts.

Critical Monitoring Priorities:

Senate committee scheduling and markup timeline development

Industry coalition building efforts supporting passage

Environmental group legal strategy development for potential challenges

State government positioning regarding federal permitting reforms

Hillary Bright emphasised that the Senate now has a critical opportunity to advance permitting reform and deliver the certainty needed to unlock investment and accelerate large-scale energy development. This perspective reflects widespread industry recognition that Senate action represents the legislation's most significant remaining hurdle.

How Can Businesses Prepare for Potential Changes?

Energy sector companies should begin preparing for potential SPEED Act implementation while maintaining flexibility regarding timeline and scope uncertainties. Strategic preparation could enable more effective response to regulatory changes when they occur.

Business Preparation Strategies:

Project pipeline optimisation for potential acceleration opportunities

Regulatory compliance framework updates anticipating new requirements

Stakeholder engagement plan modifications addressing streamlined processes

Investment timing considerations based on implementation scenarios

Companies with projects currently in permitting processes should evaluate potential benefits from SPEED Act provisions while maintaining compliance with existing requirements. This dual-track approach could position organisations to capitalise on regulatory improvements without compromising current approval progress.

The American energy infrastructure landscape stands at a potential turning point where decades of regulatory complexity may give way to more streamlined development processes. Success in navigating this transition will require careful attention to legislative developments, strategic preparation for multiple scenarios, and continued engagement with evolving regulatory frameworks. The ultimate impact will depend on implementation effectiveness, stakeholder adaptation, and the broader economic and political environment surrounding energy policy development. The SPEED Act passage in the House represents just the beginning of what could be a transformative period for American energy infrastructure development.

Actual results may vary significantly based on implementation details, legal challenges, and changing political or economic conditions. Stakeholders should conduct independent analysis and consult qualified advisors before making investment or strategic decisions based on this information.

name: Detroit and Evs
title: Ford Follows Ram's Lead, Pulls the Plug on the All-Electric Lightning - MoparInsiders
description:
Ford has effectively killed the all-electric F-150 Lightning as we know it and is pivoting to an extended-range electric vehicle (EREV) strategy for its next-generation electric pickup.
Sales of large, fully electric trucks have not met early expectations, especially when real-world towing, cold weather, and long-distance use come into play.
Instead of doubling down on a pure EV, Ford is rethinking its entire strategy.
Ford estimates the upcoming Lightning EREV will deliver more than 700 miles of total driving range.
Ford hasn’t released detailed specs yet for its Lightning EREV, nor has it confirmed a launch date.
text:
For the better part of the last decade, Detroit has pushed hard toward fully electric pickup trucks. Some of that momentum is now slowing, and the market is speaking loudly. Earlier this year, Ram made headlines by backing away from a pure battery-electric Ram 1500 REV and instead putting its full weight behind the extended-range electric Ramcharger. At the time, critics questioned the move.

Now, those critics are getting their answer—straight from Dearborn.

Ford has effectively killed the all-electric F-150 Lightning as we know it and is pivoting to an extended-range electric vehicle (EREV) strategy for its next-generation electric pickup. In other words, Ford is following the same path Ram already chose.

The writing has been on the wall for a while. Sales of large, fully electric trucks have not met early expectations, especially when real-world towing, cold weather, and long-distance use come into play. Ford has already stopped producing the current F-150 Lightning, repurposing the Rouge Electric Vehicle Center to build gas-powered F-Series trucks. What was once described as a temporary shift is now permanent.

Instead of doubling down on a pure EV, Ford is rethinking its entire strategy.

The next-generation F-150 Lightning will no longer be a battery-only truck. When it returns, it will be built on an EREV architecture—an electric drivetrain backed by a gasoline engine that works strictly as a generator. The wheels are still driven by electric motors, but the onboard engine eliminates the biggest complaint EV truck owners have voiced: range anxiety.

Ford estimates the upcoming Lightning EREV will deliver more than 700 miles of total driving range. That figure alone explains why the company is willing to absorb a massive financial hit—roughly $19.5 billion—after already launching and developing the Lightning EV program.

This is where Ram’s earlier decision starts to look less controversial and more forward-thinking.

Stellantis initially planned to offer two electric Ram 1500 models: a full battery-electric REV and the extended-range Ramcharger. As the EV truck market softened, Ram delayed and eventually canceled the pure EV, choosing to focus exclusively on the EREV solution. That decision now appears aligned with where customer demand is actually headed.

Ford CEO Jim Farley summed up the reasoning bluntly, saying, “Rather than spend billions more on these large EVs that we had planned that have no path to profitability, we’re going to pour our investments into higher margin areas — more American-built trucks, more American-built vans, hybrids across our lineup, and even affordable EVs built in Kentucky. And we’re going to go into the energy storage business in the Midwest, make our country stronger,” Farley said to Fox News.

That statement signals a broader industry shift. It’s no longer EV-at-any-cost. It’s about building trucks that people can afford, use, and rely on—especially in America’s heartland, where towing, hauling, and long distances are part of everyday life.

Volkswagen’s Scout brand has also announced plans for extended-range electric trucks and SUVs, further reinforcing that EREV technology is becoming the new bridge between internal combustion and full electrification.

Meanwhile, Ram is preparing to bring its EREV truck to market first. The 2026 Ram 1500 REV—formerly known as the Ramcharger—is engineered to calm range anxiety without sacrificing performance. It pairs a liquid-cooled 92 kWh battery with a 3.6-liter Pentastar V6 that functions solely as a generator. Total system output checks in at 647 horsepower and 610 lb.-ft. of torque, good for a 0–60 mph run in about 4.5 seconds.

Ram is targeting up to 690 miles of total range, along with a towing capacity of up to 14,000 lbs and a payload rating of 2,625 lbs. It also supports bi-directional charging, allowing owners to power homes, job sites, or equipment directly from the truck.

Ford hasn’t released detailed specs yet for its Lightning EREV, nor has it confirmed a launch date. What it has confirmed is direction—and that direction mirrors Ram’s playbook almost step for step.

The pure electric half-ton pickup may not be dead forever, but for now, the market has spoken. Extended-range electric trucks are emerging as the most practical solution for American truck buyers. Ram got there first. Ford just admitted it was right.

name: Clean Energy
title: The Battery Boom Is Reshaping Power Markets - Yahoo Finance
description:
In addition to the United States, battery storage capacity is expanding in various other markets, as governments better understand the benefits of boosting renewable energy reliability.
In Mexico, experts believe the country’s battery storage capacity could expand significantly in the coming years.
Skysense currently runs almost 200 MWh of storage capacity and expects to roll out an additional 300 MWh by 2026.
The South Asian country has seen record-low bids to develop its battery storage systems, with a lack of economic viability as well as safety risks potentially deterring investors.
There has been a battery storage boom in certain parts of the world, as governments and energy companies invest in expanding capacity to support a green transition.
text:
In addition to the United States, battery storage capacity is expanding in various other markets, as governments better understand the benefits of boosting renewable energy reliability. In Mexico, experts believe the country’s battery storage capacity could expand significantly in the coming years.

Enrique Garduño, the CEO of the energy equipment company Skysense, said that Mexico will likely experience “the storage boom in 2027, 2028, and 2029,” driven by regulatory updates, rapid renewable energy growth, and the maturation of storage technologies. Skysense currently runs almost 200 MWh of storage capacity and expects to roll out an additional 300 MWh by 2026. Garduño explained that “It’s a very open government that is genuinely listening to the private sector.” In addition, “We are buying, installing and selling storage systems at less than half the price of three or four years ago.”

Skysense has partnered with China’s BYD Energy Storage to expand its capacity, and BYD’s “MC Cube-T BESS” platform will power the technology. The firm’s North America Vice President of Sales, Oscar Su, stated, “Expanding into a high-potential region such as Latin America is a key step for us… We bring nearly 30 years of battery R&D and the world’s largest power battery production capacity.”

Meanwhile, there are high hopes for India’s battery storage sector, but more needs to be done to attract investment. The South Asian country has seen record-low bids to develop its battery storage systems, with a lack of economic viability as well as safety risks potentially deterring investors. India is aiming to double its renewable energy capacity to 500 GW by 2030, but without a rapid growth in its battery storage capacity, it will be unable to provide a reliable power supply without continuing to rely heavily on fossil fuels.

There has been a battery storage boom in certain parts of the world, as governments and energy companies invest in expanding capacity to support a green transition. However, some parts of the world are lagging, which could cause the shift away from fossil fuels to renewable alternatives to be slower than anticipated unless greater investment is made in the sector.

By Felicity Bradstock for Oilprice.com
